positive.review:
worst game ever.

I’ve been playing this since the “early-days-when-no-one-knew-what-the-hell-they-were-doing” era, and somehow I’m still not good enough to justify the years I’ve put into it. One match I’m a mechanical god; the next, I can’t hit a stationary ball if my life depended on it.

But that’s the charm. It’s the perfect blend of “I hate this game” and “queue up again,” and I keep coming back like I’ve got something to prove. Spoiler: I don’t. But here I am anyway.

When it’s good, it’s electric. When it’s bad, it builds character. Either way, it’s been part of my routine for so long that quitting now would feel like abandoning a childhood pet.

Rocket League – Fast, Fun, and Still One of the Best Multiplayer Games Out There

Rocket League remains one of the most addictive and downright fun games ever made. The concept alone—soccer with rocket-powered cars—sounds wild, but once you’re boosting across the arena, flying through the air, and pulling off insane saves, it becomes clear why the game has kept such a massive following for years. Every match feels fast, energetic, and packed with memorable moments.

The soundtrack is fantastic, too. Rocket League has always had a knack for putting together high-energy tracks that perfectly match the speed and intensity of each game. Whether you're grinding ranked matches or warming up in free play, the music keeps the adrenaline flowing.

One of Rocket League’s greatest strengths is how much you can make the game your own. The amount of car customization is unbelievable—decals, boosts, wheels, goal explosions, toppers, trails, and more. It lets you create a ride that feels uniquely yours, no matter your playstyle.

There’s also no shortage of ways to play. Standard modes, Rumble, Drop Shot, Hoops, Snow Day, tournaments, casual, competitive—the variety keeps things fresh, especially if you jump between modes with friends. And thanks to full cross-platform play, it’s easier than ever to team up no matter what system everyone’s on. That alone makes Rocket League feel more accessible and community-driven than ever.

If there’s one downside, it’s that the game was even better before the introduction of season passes. The older progression system felt more straightforward and rewarding. Still, despite the shift toward the seasonal model, the core gameplay remains as tight, thrilling, and endlessly replayable as it’s always been.

Overall, Rocket League is a masterpiece of competitive fun—easy to pick up, tough to master, and packed with personality. Even after all these years, there’s nothing else quite like it.

Rocket League can be a super casual game to play with your friends. You'll spend hours laughing and trying your best to hit the ball just to whiff but you keep coming back for more. It is fun for the whole family. 

Then you try and get better, and you think you're getting really good at the game. When you get better at Rocket League you realize just how bad you truly are. The skill ceiling is unbelievably high. Watch a few RLCS matches and you will see that there really is no skill ceiling. Players keep getting better with every passing year. 

For me, Rocket League is a 10/10 game. I started playing the game on a free play weekend on Xbox in 2017. I started the game not expecting much. But that weekend with friends was the most fun I've had on a game in a long time. I was instantly hooked. We would talk about Rocket League while at work all day, anxiously waiting to get home to hop on the game and play for hours on end. We organized tournaments with friends at work to determine who was the "best" Rocket League player. 

After several hundred hours on Xbox I made the switch to PC. I fell in love with trading items and improving my rank. The switch to PC instantly improved my performance. I jumped an entire rank just from the increase in frame rate and input delay. I was having a blast with this game. 

Epic Games purchased Rocket League and eventually removed trading and turned the game free-to-play. I was disappointed in the removal of item trading, but the change to free-to-play was a welcome one. I had many more friends try the game and enjoy it. The game in its current state is a shell of its former self. I still highly recommend the game to new players. Its worth the time to check it out!

negative.review: Trаsh game, trаsh players, trаsh balance, trаsh servers, trаsh policy, trаsh 15 y.o. engine, trаsh physics, trаsh graphics, trаsh trading system, trаsh community, trаsh moderators, trаsh devs, trаsh tim piggy.
Ever since Epic bought Psyonix, the game has only gotten worse. It’s a shame. Epic games is a shitty company.
No, I'm not creating an Epic account to play a game that used to work without an Epic account.

This game is a joke now. I’ve been playing Rocket League since 2015, back when Psyonix ran it and it actually felt like a passion project. The moment Epic Games took over, the whole thing started going downhill fast.

First, they shove Epic account linking down your throat. If anything goes wrong, you get dumb errors about your account already being linked, progress not syncing, connection issues, all that nonsense. You don’t even feel like you own your damn account anymore – Epic does.

Then they killed trading. One of the best parts of the game – building an inventory, trading with friends, and actually feeling rewarded for grinding – just deleted so it fits their precious item shop system. Whole trading community wiped for “business reasons.” Zero respect for the players who kept this game alive.

The Blueprint / Item Shop system is pure greed. Prices are ridiculous, everything is overvalued, and it’s obvious they care more about squeezing money out of skins than fixing the game. It doesn’t feel like a fun game with cosmetics anymore; it feels like a store with some outdated gameplay attached.

And the actual matches? Trash. Bots everywhere, smurfs every rank, cheaters, and people abusing the report system. You can get banned off spam reports while griefers and toxic clowns keep playing. Ranked doesn’t feel competitive; it just feels rigged and low-effort.

The servers and ping are embarrassing. Random lag spikes, input delay, hit detection feeling off, and half the time you’re fighting the server more than the other team. For a game this old and this big, it shouldn’t run like some free mobile rip-off.

Rocket League under Psyonix felt special. Rocket League under Epic feels like a cash-grab zombie being kept alive just long enough to milk the shop dry. If you’re a new player, you’ll never know how good this game used to be. If you’ve been here since 2015, you know exactly how hard they ruined it.

Genuinely, I used to love the game. I knew Epic Games bought it a while ago, and I also know we were still able to play through steam.

I tried logging in today only to realise that I have to log into the Epic Games online services, and connect it to an Epic Games account. Something that in and off itself is annoying, but not something deal breaking. When I realise that I can not connect it to my existing account, because the account I try to connect RL to is already an existing account (of course, I am trying to connect it to something existing), and have to create a new account, I can't deal with it. Especially with how Epic Games runs their company and gaming platform.

Sad to say, I can no longer play Rocket League. Shame. It is a really fun game that I wanted to get back into.
Well, there are plenty of good games, but a childhood favourite will always hold a special place in one's heart.

Rocket League is the perfect game if you enjoy questioning every life choice that led you to this moment. You’ll queue up thinking, “Hey, maybe this time I’ll have competent teammates,” only to be immediately paired with someone who treats the ball like it’s allergic to their car and they think they’re top-tier while performing like they’re in the tutorial.

You can spend hundreds of hours mastering mechanics and none of it matters when your teammates triple commit and then they backflip into the ball and own goal for the third time. "What a Save!"

The other team will play like they’re scrimming for the RLCS redirecting passes with pixel-perfect precision while being unranked.

And don’t get me started on the ranked system. You win five games in a row? Congrats, +1 MMR. Lose once because someone decided they’re now a freestyler? Boom, -900 MMR and you’re back in Plat with people still trying to figure out how to hit the ball on kickoff. 

But you know what? You’ll keep playing. Because every once in a while, you hit that one clean double-tap and suddenly you believe again. That’s the most toxic part of all — the hope.

This game seriously feels like one of the worst things ever created sometimes. The matchmaking alone is enough to drive you insane, one match you get teammates who can’t hit an open net, and the next you’re up against people who play like they’re in a world championship.  

What makes it even worse is how the actual gameplay punishes you for trying to play correctly. You can be the better player in every way, but you still end up losing to people who just mindlessly demo, ball-chase, and fling themselves at every challenge without thinking for even half a second. They don’t rotate, they don’t position, they don’t do anything remotely smart… but somehow it works. And it’s infuriating.

Meanwhile, the moment you try to play with some structure, the game finds a way to screw you over. The ball bounces the worst way possible, your teammate misses the simplest touch on earth, and the opponents get some miracle 50/50 that sends the ball straight into your net. It feels like the game is actively working against you.

Rocket League is such a fun concept and a really neat way to transfer the "driving" controller skill-set into something that isn't just racing on a track. I really had fun playing it and I think it's absolutely worth purchasing for most users -- however...

Support for my platform has been discontinued, so I'm no longer able to play online. Playing online is by far the funnest way to play this game - human players are so much better and more interesting to compete against than the bots. It's such a bummer to have been able to play online in the past, but to now not be able to play online.
